Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Story: My phone buzzed just as I pulled up to the curb, the meter still running from my last fare. It was my younger brother, texting: “Hey, we’re all at the park. Come join us!” I could picture them—my siblings, laughing, tossing a frisbee, probably wondering why I always missed out. I wanted to be there, to show I cared, to be the sister who included herself, who built those memories with them. But as I glanced in the rearview mirror, my passenger’s anxious eyes met mine. “My train leaves in twenty minutes,” she said, voice tight. The station was clear across town, and traffic was already thickening. She was counting on me to get her there safely and on time. My hands tightened on the wheel. I felt the pull—my family expecting me to be present, my passenger needing me to be professional. I could hear my brother’s laughter in my mind, but also the ticking clock for the woman in my back seat. I sat at the intersection, torn, the weight of both roles pressing down, unsure which direction to turn.
